title: Flashing Lights and Floaters
author: Bhavana Sharma
keyPoints: Floaters usually represent age related changes (liquefaction) of the vitreous
Floaters occur in 70% of the population
Acute onset flashing lights and floaters should undergo a dilated fundus examination
redFlags: New onset floaters with flashing lights

q1.text: Is this a sudden onset of flashing lights and/or floaters?

q2.text: Are there any visual field defects or curtain-like shadows?

q3.text: What is the nature of the floaters?

answers.text: Multiple new floaters with flashing lights

q4.text: Is there any tobacco dust or pigmented cells in the vitreous?

q5.text: Any associated symptoms (photophobia, pain, reduced vision)?

q6.text: Are the floaters interfering with daily activities?

urgent1.text: URGENT: Possible retinal detachment. Immediate ophthalmology referral required. Dilated fundus examination and B-scan ultrasound. Consider same-day vitreoretinal consultation.

urgent2.text: URGENT: Tobacco dust suggests retinal tear. Immediate dilated examination required. Urgent vitreoretinal referral for possible laser treatment or surgery.

dilated_exam.text: Perform dilated fundus examination. Look for retinal tears, detachment, or posterior vitreous detachment. If normal, reassure patient but arrange follow-up in 2-4 weeks.

routine_follow.text: Routine ophthalmology follow-up. Advise patient to return immediately if symptoms worsen or new visual field defects develop.

specialist_referral.text: Refer to vitreoretinal specialist for assessment. May consider vitrectomy if floaters significantly impact quality of life.

reassurance.text: Reassure patient that floaters are common age-related changes. Advise to return if sudden increase in floaters or flashing lights develop.
